body:
I don't think we want to go this route. Applications should implement it the way they see fit. I know it's hard to get right, but it's impossible to please everyone: why OpenSSL and not gnuTLS / LibreSSL / PolarSSL / what have you? Do we add wrappers for all cert management functions or let people just use OpenSSL's API? What about DTLS? And TLS over Unix domain sockets?

I'm very -1 on this.

/cc @bnoordhuis @piscisaureus

The approach libevent took seems to work fairly well for people. In other languages, Twitsted and EventMachine did a good job also.

I'm not advocating for OpenSSL in particular, but some sort of out-of-the-box TLS solution would be very handy.

SSL/TLS support comes up often; not so much as a feature request but as a 'how do I integrate libuv with openssl?' kind of question on SO and other places.  As such, I think it would be useful to have out-of-the-box support but it doesn't necessarily have to be part of libuv itself; it should be doable as a separate library on top of libuv that lives under the libuv project umbrella but with possibly a different set of maintainers.

If anyone is interested in taking that on, now would be a good time to step up. :-)

> why OpenSSL and not gnuTLS / LibreSSL / PolarSSL / what have you?

curl supports those by means of an abstraction layer that shims the largest common denominator, with some library-specific escape hatches.  Presumably our hypothetical libuv-ssl would employ a similar tactic.

> TLS over Unix domain sockets?

Do people actually do that?  How does verification work?

> Do people actually do that? How does verification work?

I have no idea, I made it up on the spot :-)
+1 for considering this as enhancement. I am also assuming DTLS for udp will also included?

@bnoordhuis So think a better way would be to have an addition that statically compiles into libuv with that extra support? I mean, is there really anything that couldn't be done only using libuv's public API?
@trevnorris Nothing like that, it would be completely unbundled; it'd just be a known-good library that is vetted and maintained in lockstep with libuv proper.
A libuv user announced this on the mailing list today: https://github.com/deleisha/libuv-ssl

+1 including DTLS.

Some thoughts:
- Applications _may_ want to choose SSL implementation, but I think they will be happy with any quality solution that you can provide.
- What applications definitely do not want to do is the entire integration from scratch every time they want to turn on SSL.
- SSL is already a commodity that ships inside every OS, so infrastructures that don't provide it in a simple switch only add friction to its users.

Cheers.
Just announce though that a library supports SSL with libuv: https://github.com/clibs/net :)
Was planning to work on it once issue #275 is in place.
I move to close this.  The plan is to land TLS support in libuv-extras, when ready, not here.  Thoughts @libuv/collaborators ?
